Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 12:25PM - edited Jul 24, 2008 01:18PM by Tucheta In my country, compressive sleeves are simply not available at all and awareness / knowledge about LE is very limitted. The doctors provided me only with basic information after my mastectomy so most of what I know about LE is from internet and especially from your most valuable postings on this subject (thank you all so much for your generosity in sharing!).. As for  LE Therapists... I only found some who are doing Lymph Drainage Massage, however I am not sure if they are reliable since I am not aware of the existance of any official certification here My main concern is that I will have to fly due to my work and I would certainly not want to do it without a sleeve, even thoug I do not have LE yet. I could order one from another country, over internet, but I understand it has to be "customised". Is there any way I can determine myself what kind of sleeve I need? I would probably be able to measure my arm but as far as I understand the degree of compression is also important and that's why you get a prescription from doctor. Any ideas what to do in this case? Would a less-than-perfectly-fitted-sleeve be better than no-sleeve-at-all? Thanks so much Ralu

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2008 05:29AM Tucheta wrote: I finished chemo on Friday, Oct 24th, and will be starting radiation on Nov. 12th. I only had a very brief discussion with the radiation oncologist (less than a minute!). He basically said not to worry about it and we'll discuss more on the 12th. So at this stage I don't even know how long the treatment will take. I am so happy chemo is over - and can't wait to have my eyelashes back! - but I am also concerned about radiation side effects, especially burning and LE . Hope I can find some prevention tips on these boards...
Posts.Title: November 2008 Rads Group HensonChi Ivy

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 12:33PM Tucheta wrote: Chemo finished Oct 24th 2008, 4 weeks of rads finished Dec 19th 2008. Terrible fatigue after the first week of rads.  I had fatigue with chemo too, but it was different and not so constant. With rads I felt so tired, I wished I could lie on the floor in the middle of the day and sleep. Maybe it was in part because I had the treatment very early in the morning and was going directly to work afterwards. The fatigue got better about 2-3 weeks after finishing rads. Now I am on Herceptin since January and still get suddenly tired in the afternoon. Probably some remaining SE of chemo and rads.

Posts.Content: Tucheta wrote: Hello Ladies, Are you in the mood for something different today? Today is 1st of March and in Romania we celebrate the beginning of spring. I thought I'd share with you a little bit about our ancient tradition for 1st of March, called "Martisor" (which could be approximately translated as a diminutive of March or "little March"). On this day men are offering women little Martisor amulets or talismans - usually a little piece of decoration representing a flower, heart, horseshoe etc, on a white and red string. Women wear them pinned on their blouses until 9 March, and the Martisor is supposed to bring health and good luck and strength and a beautiful springtime. You can find out more if you google Martisor. So here is a virtual Martisor for each of you, dear ladies, and may it bring you health and good luck! (Hope I'll manage to include the picture.)  Ralu  Dx 1/8/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 2, 2/13 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 1st of March Tradition Tucheta aprilintexas

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2008 05:27PM Tucheta wrote: I have heard of lumpectomies being done even if the biopsy came back benign, but not because the doctor doubted the accuracy of the biopsy result, but because of the risk of the lump turning malign in time. So, more as a preventative procedure. I have no idea what are the criteria for establishing this risk or how reliable an mri is. On the other hand, I think that the path report you get from a lumpectomy is more reliable than the one from biopsy, probably because you can analyse a larger area. Best wishes to you and your sister!

I don't think you should worry about doing chemo first, it's good that you are getting treatment and they will be able to monitor the response Hugs

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 08:15AM Tucheta wrote: Sisterinspirit, I only wear my sleeve and gauntlet for prevention, when flying, and if someone asks, I just say it's something like compression stockings, only for my arm. Most people know about compression stockings and about thrombosis, so are happy with this answer. I just don't feel like sharing my medical history with perfect strangers, and I know trying to explain would only generate more questions.  If I am asked by someone who knows about my BC, then I try to explain about LE.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 01:30PM Tucheta wrote: I am in a similar situation as mbpetit, the difference is that I really have no LE specialist or fitter. I ordered off-the-shelf, on internet, did my own measuring and chose Jobst because I simply wasn't able to find out where I fit in the Juzo sizing chart. I guess I am not that smart . It took them almost a month to get here but now I am the happy owner of two sets of arm sleeves and gauntlets: one set is 15/20 mmHg, the other one is 20/30 mmHg. Based on the advice I've got from Binney in another thread, I thought for prevention (my case) the lower compression one should be fine. The second one is for backup or... for later. I had no problems putting them on, following the instructions on the package, which are exactly as shrink and Binney explained, but I was sooooo afraid that "something" might happen that I took them off after 15 minutes. I felt so stupid and helpless. I did not notice any change in color, but there were very fine marks on the skin, like an imprint from the texture. Does this mean they are too tight? Now that I've read Binney's recommendations I feel encouraged to try wearing them for an hour over the weekend and will try to be less paranoid. Some other questions: 1. The wide bands of the gauntlet and arm sleeve are overlapping. Is this good or bad? 2. For prevention, would it be wise to wear these garments regularly, e.g. during the night, not just for flying? 3. If the risk for arm LE is so high when flying, isn't there a high risk for truncal LE too? Thank you all so much for all the help and information you provide Ralu

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2008 06:16PM Tucheta wrote: One of my doctors advised me to get into the habit of holding on a top button of my shirt or a necklace, in other words to find a "reason" to keep my arm up, instead of hanging down, when I don't use it. I haven't found this recommendation in any of the stuff I read about LE prevention but it does seem to make sense. It's a way of elevating your arm when you can't use pillows. Any opinions? Do you think it can do any harm? Thanks.  Ralu
